debug_log.description: The log file to write debugging output to

environment.description: The HSDP environment to configure for

mdm_url.description: The Connect MDM URL to use

notification_url.description: The HSDP Notification service base URL to use

org_admin_password.description: The password of the Organization Admin

org_admin_username.description: The username of the Organization Admin

region.description: The HSDP region to configure for

retry_max.description: Maximum number of retries for API requests

s3creds_url.description: The HSDP S3 Credentials instance URL

service_id.description: The service ID to use as Organization Admin

service_private_key.description: The private key of the service ID

uaa_password.description: The password of the Cloudfoundry account to use

uaa_url.description: The URL of the UAA server

uaa_username.description: The username of the Cloudfoundry account to use

triggers.description: A map of arbitrary strings that, when changed, will force the 'hsdp_edge_sync' resource to be replaced, re-sync conifg with the device.

block.description: The `hsdp_edge_sync` resource syncs device discovery to the actual device.

global_reference_id.description: Reference identifier defined by the provisioning user. Recommend to not set this and let Terraform generate a UUID for you.

proposition_id.description: The proposition ID (GUID) to attach this a application to.

wait_for_delete.description: Blocks until the application delete has completed. Default: false. The application delete process can take some time as all its associated resources like services and clients are removed recursively. This option is useful for ephemeral environments where the same application might be recreated shortly after a destroy operation.

block.description: Manage HSDP IAM application under a proposition

access_token_lifetime.description: Lifetime of the access token in seconds. If not specified, system default life time (1800 secs) will be considered.

application_id.description: The application ID to attach this client to.

consent_implied.description: Flag when enabled, the resource owner will not be asked for consent during authorization flows.

default_scopes.description: Default scopes. You do not have to specify these explicitly when requesting a token.

disabled.description: True if the client is disabled e.g. because the managing Organization is disabled.

global_reference_id.description: Reference identifier defined by the provisioning user. This reference Identifier will be carried over to identify the provisioned resource across deployment instances.

id_token_lifetime.description: Lifetime of the jwt token generated in case openid scope is enabled for the client. If not specified, system default life time (3600 secs) will be considered.

password.description: The password to use (8-16 chars, at least one capital, number, special char).

redirection_uris.description: List of valid RedirectionURIs for this client.

refresh_token_lifetime.description: Lifetime of the refresh token in seconds. If not specified, system default life time (2592000 secs) will be considered.

response_types.description: Examples of response types are 'code id_token', 'token id_token', etc.

scopes.description: List of supported scopes for this client.

type.description: The type of the client. Either 'Public' or 'Confidential'.

block.description: A client identity describes a version of a registered application, its access scopes, and its credentials. Typically, the client identity represents a foreground (or user-facing) application. A client acts on other resources.

application_id.description: The application ID (GUID) this device should be attached to.

for_test.description: When set to true this device is marked as a test device.

is_active.description: Controls if this device is active or not.

login_id.description: The login id of the device.

organization_id.description: The organization ID (GUID) this device should be attached to.

registration_date.description: The date the device was registered.

block.description: Block describing external ID of this device.

These resources represent device accounts in IAM. Typically, devices contain information that identifies a devices uniqueness, intended use, credentials, and other details to track the device back to its proposition

format.description: The template format. Must be 'HTML' currently.

link.description: A clickable link, depends on the template type.

locale.description: The locale of the template. When not specified the template will become the default. Only a single default template is allowed of course.

managing_organization.description: The Id of the IAM Org to apply this email template to.

subject.description: The Subject line of the email.

block.description: There are certain IAM flows that trigger email notifications to the user. The email delivered to users will use the IAM specific email template by default. This resource allows you to manage template for your HSDP IAM organization.

devices.description: The list of IAM device identity IDs to include in this group.

drift_detection.description: When enabled, the provider will perform additional API calls to determine if any changes were made outside of Terraform to user and service assignments of this group.

roles.description: The list of role IDS to assign to this group.

services.description: The list of service identity IDs to include in this group.

users.description: The list of user IDs to include in this group. The provider only manages this list of users. Existing users added by others means to the group by the provider. It is not practical to manage hundreds or thousands of users this way of course.

block.description: Organization administrators can create groups to help organize users by teams, projects, or user function. Groups must be uniquely named within the organization in which they were created. Admins can add a single identity to one or more groups. They can also assign one or more roles to a group. All users in a group will share the permissions that are associated with the role.

active.description: Weather the organization is active or not.

display_name.description: The display name to use for this organization.

external_id.description: An optional external identifier for this organization.

name.description: The name of the IAM Organization.

wait_for_delete.description: Blocks until the organization delete has completed. Default: false. The organization delete process can take some time as all its associated resources like users, groups, roles etc. are removed recursively. This option is useful for ephemeral environments where the same organization might be recreated shortly after a destroy operation.

block.description: An organization is a container that owns sub-organizations, groups, and users, as well as other identities like devices and services.

wait_for_delete.description: Blocks until the proposition delete has completed. Default: false. The proposition delete process can take some time as all its associated resources like applications and services are removed recursively. This option is useful for ephemeral environments where the same proposition might be recreated shortly after a destroy operation.

block.description: A proposition represents a deployable solution as a unique identity in a hosting organization. It must have one or more independently manageable applications.

managing_organization.description: The managing organization of the role.

permissions.description: List of permissions IDs assigned to this role.

ticket_protection.description: Removal protection of some ticket only permissions.

block.description: Organization administrators can create roles for the users, services, and devices that interact with their organizations. Roles are a collection of permissions and provide a way to manage the assignment of permissions to users. Permissions are privileges that define what a user is allowed to do. The roles can contain permissions from one or more applications and services. That is, if there are two products being used, permissions from both products can be added to one role. Roles are assigned to a group

application_id.description: The application ID this service falls under.

default_scopes.description: Default scopes. You do not have to specify these explicitly when requesting a token.

expires_on.description: The expiration date of the service credentials.

organization_id.description: The organization this service falls under. Relationship established through application.

private_key.description: The active private of the service.

scopes.description: List of supported scopes for this service.

self_managed_certificate.description:
X509 Certificate in PEM format. When provided, overrides the generated certificate / private key combination of the IAM service. This gives you full control over the credentials. When not specified, a private key will be generated by IAM.
Mutually exclusive with `self_managed_private_key`

self_managed_certificate_nonsensitive.description:
X509 Certificate in PEM format. When provided, overrides the generated certificate / private key combination of the IAM service. This gives you full control over the credentials. When not specified, a private key will be generated by IAM.
Mutually exclusive with `self_managed_certificate`

self_managed_expires_on.description:
Sets the certificate validity. When not specified, the certificate will have a validity of 5 years.
Only applicable when `self_managed_private_key` is used

self_managed_private_key.description:
RSA private key in PEM format. When provided, overrides the generated certificate / private key combination of the IAM service. This gives you full control over the credentials. When not specified, a private key will be generated by IAM.
Mutually exclusive with `self_managed_certificate`

token_validity.description: Access Token Lifetime (in seconds). Default: 1800 (30 minutes), Maximum: 2592000 (30 days).

validity.description: The validity of the service credentials in months.

block.description: A service identity is typically used for machine to machine identification. Unlike clients, a services can act as both resource owners and resource consumers.

access_status.description: The access status of the provider instance to the user. Depending on access level the provider might not have full access to the user. For Crossplane support we might allow just partial access to the user.

email.description: The email address of the user.

first_name.description: The first name of the user.

last_name.description: The last name of the user.

mobile.description: The optional mobile phone number of the user.

organization_id.description: The managing organization of the user.

password.description: When specified this will skip the email activation flow and immediately activate the IAM account. Very Important: you are responsible for sharing this password with the new IAM user through some channel of communication. No email will be triggered by the system. If unsure, do not set a password so the normal email activation flow is followed. Finally, any password value changes after user creation will have no effect on the users' actual password.

preferred_communication_channel.description: Preferred communication channel. Email and SMS are supported channels. Email is the default channel if e-mail address is provided. Values supported: [ email | sms ].

preferred_language.description: Language preference for all communications. Value can be a two letter language code as defined by ISO 639-1 (en, de) or it can be a combination of language code and country code (en-gb, en-us). The country code is as per ISO 3166 two letter code (alpha-2).

block.description: Users are created under an organization and are assigned to groups.

triggers.description: A map of arbitrary strings that, when changed, will force the resource to be replaced.
A map of arbitrary strings that, when changed, will force the resource to be replaced.

salt.description: Salt value to use for generating a deterministic API key

signature.description: The signature of the generated API key

domain.description: The domain associated with the service

environment.description: The environment to refer to. Defaults to the provider configured one

host.description: The host associated with the service

org_admin_username.description: The OrgAdmin username used to authenticate against IAM

region.description: The region to look up. Defaults to the provider configured one

service_id.description: The service ID used to authenticate against IAM

sliding_expires_on.description: The next quarter starting date based on the current time. Useful for setting certificate expires

url.description: The url associated with the service

block.description: A client identity describes a version of a registered application, its access scopes, and its credentials. Typically, the client identity represents a foreground (or user-facing) application. A client acts on other resources.

There are certain IAM flows that trigger email notifications to the user. The email delivered to users will use the IAM specific email template by default. This resource allows you to manage template for your HSDP IAM organization.

Organization administrators can create groups to help organize users by teams, projects, or user function. Groups must be uniquely named within the organization in which they were created. Admins can add a single identity to one or more groups. They can also assign one or more roles to a group. All users in a group will share the permissions that are associated with the role.
An organization is a container that owns sub-organizations, groups, and users, as well as other identities like devices and services.
A proposition represents a deployable solution as a unique identity in a hosting organization. It must have one or more independently manageable applications.

Organization administrators can create roles for the users, services, and devices that interact with their organizations. Roles are a collection of permissions and provide a way to manage the assignment of permissions to users. Permissions are privileges that define what a user is allowed to do. The roles can contain permissions from one or more applications and services. That is, if there are two products being used, permissions from both products can be added to one role. Roles are assigned to a group
A service identity is typically used for machine to machine identification. Unlike clients, a services can act as both resource owners and resource consumers.
Users are created under an organization and are assigned to groups.
